text:
The Crystal Palace, Sixth Avenue, east side, from 42nd to 40th Streets. The idea of an industrial exposition housed in a building of glass and iron originated in London 1851, in Hyde Park. The New York building, however, was smaller than its London predecessor, and entirely different in appearance. It was originally planned to build the Crystal Palace in Madison Square Park, but the protests of residents in that fashionable neighborhood compelled the abandonment of the scheme. The land in back of the Croton Reservoir, now Bryant Park, but then known as Reservoir Square, was leased from the City for a nominal rental of one dollar a year. Construction work began in 1852, and the building, housing the first World's Fair to be held in the United States, was formally opened on July 14, 1853, by President Franklin Pierce. The building, however, was not a financial success, as its London predecessor had been. The city took possession in May of 1858, and on October 5 of that year, while the City Fathers were debating the question of the removal of the building, and while the annual exposition of the American Institute was in progress, fire broke out, and the building was completely destroyed. The land was then converted by the city into the present Bryant Park. This is a photograph made for the sake of preservation from the original, a rare and badly faded photograph, whose plate has long ago been lost. The original is on deposit in the Library.

About 1853.

J. Loeffler, from P. L. Sperr Collection.

42nd Street and Bryant Park, from Sixth to Fifth Avenues. On the south side of the street, in the park, the Queensboro subway extension is in the early stages of construction. Notice the broadcasting station on the top of Aeolian Hall. 1923.

Brown Brothers.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.

42nd Street, west from and including Sixth Avenue, showing the new Bush Terminal Building on the south side of the street.
The building whose roof is shown in the right foreground is the Bryant Park Arcade at the N.E. corner of Sixth Avenue and 42nd Street; it will later be replaced by Stern Brothers' new building.
About 1923.

Ewing Galloway.

folder: 42nd Street (West) & Between 5th and 6th Avenues., Manhattan, NY
text:
These photos were taken from:
65 W. 39th Street, at the N. E. corner of Sixth Avenue,
(general view northeastward).

They show:
Two views across the eastern end of Bryant Park and the rear of the New York Public Library towards the Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street intersection. To the left, on the latter thoroughfare, is a low building occupied by the Stern Brothers Department Store, the 18 story Aeolian Building and the mammoth Salmon Tower Building. To the right of the latter are, the Lefcourt National Building and
the Grand Central Building

February 28, 1930
Views: 1 and 2

text:
These photos were taken from:
65 W. 39th Street, at the N. E. corner of Sixth Avenue,
(general view northeastward).

They show:
Two views across the eastern end of Bryant Park and the rear of the New York Public Library towards the Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street intersection. To the left, on the latter thoroughfare, is a low building occupied by the Stern Brothers Department Store, the 18 story Aeolian Building and the mammoth Salmon Tower Building. To the right of the latter are, the Lefcourt National Building and
the Grand Central Building

February 28, 1930
Views: 1 and 2

West 42nd Street, east from Sixth Ave., and showing prominently Bryant Park, which is on the south side of the afore mentioned street. The New York Public Library is at the eastern end of this park and it faces onto the west side of Fifth Ave., between 40th and 42nd Streets. Shown under construction is the skyscraper, No. 500 Fifth Ave., at the N.W. corner of 42nd Street. Adjoining same is the Salmon Tower, with the Morris Building (formerly Aeolian Hall) and Stern's Dept. Store westward. Across the Library Building is silhouetted the mid-town 42nd Street skyscraper district; with its Chrysler, Lincoln, Chanin, Lefcourt and Colonial and 10 East 40th Street Buildings. This picture donated to the New York Public Library, by Mr. Hoffman on March 27th 1937.

June 1930.

Copyrighted by William Frange.

(1)
Bryant Park and New York Public Library, looking east from the Bush Terminal Building west of Sixth Avenue, showing the sky-scrapers of the Grand Central region. The four tall ones, from left to right, are: the Chrysler Building on the N.E. corner of Lexington Avenue and 42nd Street, the Lincoln Building (almost completely hiding the Chanin Building) at 60 East 42nd Street, the Lefcourt Colonial Building at the S.E. corner of Madison Avenue and 41st Street, and 10 East 40th Street at the right. At the time of this picture the New York Trust Building, on the S.E. corner of Madison Avenue and 40th Street, has not yet been erected.
July 30, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, but also including 500 Fifth Avenue, the skyscraper under construction at the N.W. corner of Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street.
July 30, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same.
August 19, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

May 27, 1930.

The same; the Federal Hall replica seen through a gap in the trees planted along Sixth Avenue. This photograph was made the month following the Washington Bicentennial Pageant. "Federal Hall" was kept open all year as a public exhibit.
May 15, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

The same, a closer and unobstructed view, showing the Federal Hall replica. This is a copy of the old New York City Hall which stood on Wall Street at Nassau, and which became the property of the Federal government when New York became the temporary capital of the country, in 1789. President Washington was inaugurated on its balcony; and that scene was reenacted here in 1932.

May 15, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: 6th Avenue and Broadway and 42nd Street, Manhattan, N.Y.
text:
General View Midtown Manhattan, West 40's and 50's: View 1 is northwestward across the area lying between Sixth Avenue and Broadway and between 42nd and 49th street. In the lower left corner is the roof of the Hippodrome and the Sixth Avenue "El". The Hotel Astor is on the upper left hand corner.

View 2 is northwestward across the West 50's seen from Radio City. In the upper right hand corner are luxurious residential hotels on Central Park South.

P. L. Sperr

View 1: June 24, 1931
View 2: December 1, 1932
title: General view - Midtown Manhattan - West 40s and 50s.

folder: 6th Avenue and Broadway and 42nd Street, Manhattan, N.Y.
text:
General View Midtown Manhattan, West 40's and 50's: View 1 is northwestward across the area lying between Sixth Avenue and Broadway and between 42nd and 49th street. In the lower left corner is the roof of the Hippodrome and the Sixth Avenue "El". The Hotel Astor is on the upper left hand corner.

View 2 is northwestward across the West 50's seen from Radio City. In the upper right hand corner are luxurious residential hotels on Central Park South.

P. L. Sperr

View 1: June 24, 1931
View 2: December 1, 1932
title: General view - Midtown Manhattan - West 40s and 50s.

text:
Sixth Avenue, north from West 42nd Street, showing the distinctive Hippodrome between 43rd and 44th Street's. The photographer's vantage point is the Wurlitzer Building, from which he is viewing northeastward. Note the Sixth Avenue Elevated.

View 2 is from the 42nd Street station of same while No. 3 is from the street level. In these views, one observes constructional details of the towering Rockefeller Center.

View 1: August 19, 1930
View 2: June 8, 1932
View 3: May 1, 1933

P. L. Sperr

42nd Street and Bryant Park, east from Sixth Avenue. July, 1932.

New York Edison Company.

42nd Street and Bryant Park, with mid-town skyscrapers in the background, east from and including 35 West 42nd Street east of Sixth Avenue. The Federal Hall replica stands behind the Public Library in the eastern half of Bryant Park. The former Aeolian Hall at 33-29 West 42nd Street is now occupied by the Morris Plan Industrial Bank. July 11, 1932.

New York Edison Company.

West 42nd Street, east from Sixth Ave. Overhead is the "L" structure that acquires its name from this Avenue.
April 3, 1933.
Irvin., Fitterman.

(1)
Demolition of the Federal Hall replica, Bryant Park, east-center the view is northeast, the year after the George Washington Bicentennial Celebration. April 24, 1933.

The center part of the Park, seen from Sixth Avenue, showing the remodelling of the Park in process under the regime of Commissioner Robert Moses, New York's first city-wide Commissioner of Parks. Prior to an enabling act passed in 1934 by the State Legislature, there was a separate Park Commissioner for each borough.

August 20, 1934.

Sixth Avenue, at W. 42nd Street, showing demolition of the Sixth Avenue "El" structure and its 42nd Street station. The photographer is viewing north-westward from a vantage point in Bryant Park towards Times Square where the Times Building appears.

April 4, 1939

Mr. Nathan Schwartz
New York Public Library

Neg A: 1376 # A-1376

Sixth Avenue, at West 42nd Street, showing portions of the "El" station at that point, prior to demolition. This, by personal observation on the part of the writer, will occur in April of this year.

The photographer is on the southbound platform and he is viewing across the tracks towards the opposite one. The stairway details are of his vantage point. The buildings here shown are at the N. W. corner.

March, 1939
Views 1-2

Wm: Herries

Sixth Avenue, at West 42nd Street, showing portions of the "El" station at that point, prior to demolition. This, by personal observation on the part of the writer, will occur in April of this year.

The photographer is on the southbound platform and he is viewing across the tracks towards the opposite one. The stairway details are of his vantage point. The buildings here shown are at the N. W. corner.

March, 1939
Views 1-2

Wm: Herries

Sixth Avenue, at W. 42nd Street, showing "El" demolition. The photographer is viewing northwestward from a corner in Bryant Park. Buildings seen in the center are on the north side of W. 42nd Street, west of Sixth Avenue. Prominent amongst these is the distinctive Times Building.

April 4, 1939

Mr. Nathan Schwartz
New York Public Library

Sixth Avenue, at W. 42nd Street, showing the demolition of the "El" structure and station. Buildings shown beyond same are at the N. W. corner of this point. At the left margin appears the Times Building.

April 4, 1939

Mr. Nathan Schwartz
New York Public Library

Neg # A.1378

Sixth Avenue, at West 42nd Street, showing final aspects of the Sixth Avenue "El" prior to demolition. The photographer, in both of these views, is standing on the downtown platform and is viewing northeastward.

No. 1 shows the fore-end of a downtown train and a news-reel photographer making the last journey. No. 2 shows a work train accumulating the wood benches that were a familiar furnishing of every station. The buildings in the background, line the east side of Sixth Avenue, north from 42nd Street. Note the Hippodrome in the 43rd-44th Street block.

March, 1939
Views: 1-2

Wm. Herries

Sixth Avenue, at West 42nd Street, showing final aspects of the Sixth Avenue "El" prior to demolition. The photographer, in both of these views, is standing on the downtown platform and is viewing northeastward.

No. 1 shows the fore-end of a downtown train and a news-reel photographer making the last journey. No. 2 shows a work train accumulating the wood benches that were a familiar furnishing of every station. The buildings in the background, line the east side of Sixth Avenue, north from 42nd Street. Note the Hippodrome in the 43rd-44th Street block.

March, 1939
Views: 1-2

Wm. Herries

Sixth Avenue, at West 42nd Street, showing transportation facilities at that point. Emphasized is the "El" station that shortly is to be demolished. SLIDE#230

The photographer is on 42nd Street and is viewing eastward across the Avenue. Bryant Park and the New York Public Library appear in the center under the "El" structure.

No. 2 is a less inclusive view; photographed from a point closer to the corner (N.W.).

March, 1939
Views 1-2

Wm. Herries

Sixth Avenue, at West 42nd Street, showing transportation facilities at that point. Emphasized is the "El" station that shortly is to be demolished. SLIDE#230

The photographer is on 42nd Street and is viewing eastward across the Avenue. Bryant Park and the New York Public Library appear in the center under the "El" structure.

No. 2 is a less inclusive view; photographed from a point closer to the corner (N.W.).

March, 1939
Views 1-2

Wm. Herries

Sixth Avenue, east side, north from West 42nd Street, and showing this thoroughfare subsequent to the demolition of the elevated line identified with same. Shortly to follow will be the old Hippodrome building. This cleared site from 43rd to 44th Street's will be used as an auto parking lot. Stern's Department Store at the right and in the background are Rockefeller Center buildings. Subway construction is progressing at this date.

Views 1, 2: May 6, 1939
View 3: September 8, 1939

P. L. Sperr

West 42nd Street, west across Sixth Avenue, showing the old "El" station at that point, prior to demolition. Views 2 & 3 detail this phase. In the background is the Times Bldg. at Times Square.

1: February 4, 1939
2&3: April 5, 1939

W. 42nd Street, west from Sixth Avenue, subsequent to the razing of the "El" structure and station. The photographer is at the S. E. corner (Bryant Park) and is viewing towards Times Square where the distinctive Times Building (Broadway) appears.

Sept 20, 1939

Mr. Nathan Schwartz
New York Public Library

Bryant Park and the New York Public Library (rear) the morning after a snowstorm. This photograph is taken from the 15th floor of the Wurlitzer Building at 116-22 West 42nd Street. On the left is 42nd Street and on the right 40th Street. Sixth Avenue is in the foreground and does not appear while Fifth Avenue is just beyond the Library.

February 16, 1940

Nathan Schwartz
New York Public Library
Photostat Division
